Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2018 08:43AM ddbaker wrote: I am 45 and been on hormone replacement therapy for 15 years. I also have very dense breasts and noticed a bruised feeling in outer quadrant of right breast and felt a lump there also. I noticed that it isn't as painful as it was a few days ago and the lump is now more of a mass. It is close to the chest wall and not free floating or round. This morning as I was putting on deodorant on the top part of my armpit I noticed a sore spot as well. Nothing swollen just sore. I was seen by my PCP on Tues and she ordered an ultrasound but it has not been scheduled as of yet. I am a little concerned and obviously curious because I have been reading these boards like crazy. I have also felt a little run down the past few months. Tired, headaches and just overall fatigue. Anyone have anything similiar?
Posts.Title: Anyone with dense breasts - lump on upper outer quadrant brady0819 ddbaker

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2015 11:40AM ddbaker wrote: I had mammo on 3/17/15 with ultrasound right after. ultrasound shows dense fibroglandular pattern with mild distortion of architecture and areas of posterior acoustic shadowing. Radiologist recommend I have an MRI. I had to wait 30 days for the MRI because I have been on HRT for 10 years (I am 42) and had to be off of it for 30 days. I stopped the HRT and MRI is scheduled April 18. My questions is, will the radiologist or MRI tech be able to tell me anything? I have heard of radiologist informing patients of abnormal MRI results.
Posts.Title: Mammogram, ultrasound, MRI Nancdancer NATSGSG

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2015 07:10AM ddbaker wrote: My area of concern is hard to detect as well due to dense breasts. Tomorrow is step 1, with the MRI, then it will be more waiting. I initially thought that since I had to wait 30 days for the MRI it must not be serious. But I am not sure if that is accurate. Hormone replacement therapy can alter the MRI picture. After reading and doing research I have decided to proceed with biopsy most likely whether it is recommended or not. It sounds like ILC is slippery to detect. I appreciate all of the responses, it helps with the waiting.
Posts.Title: Mammogram, ultrasound, MRI Nancdancer NATSGSG

Has anyone had a pinching/squeezing sensation behind the nipple and into the area where the BC was found? I do not have any dimpling or retraction.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2015 02:50PM ddbaker wrote: Could you tell me a little about your path to your diagnosis? What were the concerning terms on the mammo/ultrasound? What kind of imaging have you had and what kind of biopsy? I really appreciate your reply! :)
Posts.Title: Mammogram, ultrasound, MRI Nancdancer NATSGSG

Posts.Content: ddbaker wrote: I have had regular mammos and US's since 2010 and had a biopsy in 2010 for Paget's disease that was negative. I had my yearly mammo yesterday and immediately after the mammo I was taken in to have an ultrasound. The radiologist finished my US and said I needed to have an MRI. I received the results of both tests yesterday and my doc didn't seem to concerned but I work in the office and was able to get a copy of my imaging. The recent US mentions mild distrortion of architecture, areas of post acoustic shadowing. All in the left breast which is whereÂ I feel the mass. R breast is normal. I am 41 and been on hormone replacement therapy for almost 10 years. I have to wait 30 days before I can have the MRI because they want me to discontinue the hormones I take so they are out of my system prior to the test. Of course, working in a medical office I do what we tell others NOT to do and I immediately google the ominous phrases on the US and am certainly concerned. Anyone else have experience with anything similiar? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Should I worry? ddbaker ddbaker

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2018 08:51PM ddbaker wrote: I am 45 years old and been on Hormone Replacement Therapy for 15 years. I noticed on Sunday that my breast was sore on the outer quadrant of the right breast. I had a mammo about 3-4 months ago and it was clear. The pain has decreased but the spot is still there. It feels solid but not hard and it is not floating but closer to the chest wall. I would say in between a mass and a lump. I have always heard that breast pain is not a symptom of cancer so I am not that worried, more curious. I got into my PCP yesterday and she has ordered an ultrasound but I probably get that scheduled until next week. No strong history of BC but being on HRT for 15 years prompted me to visit my PCP.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2015 08:59PM ddbaker wrote: I am in the same boat, however; I received my MRI results and the score was a BiRads 3-probably benign and I need a repeat MRI in 6 months. This is the only year I have met my deductible and am considering proceeding with biopsy. I have heard that some cancers are sneeky and may not show up on MRI. The MRI shows a type II plateau surrounding a 5x5x3 lesion. That isn't a huge abnormality but I just WANT TO KNOW!! So frustrating! My thoughts are with each of you :)
